title: JupiterScope — Real-Time Route Efficiency Analyzer
description: A live dashboard and Telegram bot that monitors Jupiter Aggregator v6 routing decisions, comparing actual execution prices against theoretical optimal routes across Raydium, Orca, and Phoenix. Pulls swap instruction data from Jupiter's program (JUP6LkbZbjS1jKKwapdHNy74zcZ3tLUZoi5QNyVTaV4) via Helius DAS API, decodes route legs, and scores each trade's price improvement vs. direct AMM execution. Surfaces the 'Jupiter Tax' — how much worse or better aggregated routing performs versus going direct — broken down by token pair, liquidity depth, and time of day.
target_user: Solana DeFi power traders running $10K+ daily volume who suspect Jupiter routing isn't always optimal. Current pain: no visibility into whether Jupiter's route is actually the best path or whether direct Raydium/Orca swaps would save on slippage. They'd switch because this tool quantifies the hidden cost of aggregator dependency with hard numbers.
mvp_scope: 1) Helius webhook listener ingesting Jupiter v6 swap instructions in real-time, parsing route legs and extracting input/output amounts. 2) Price comparison engine that queries Raydium CLMM (CAMMCzo5YL8w4VFF8KVHrK22GGUsp5VTaW7grrKgrWqK) and Orca Whirlpool (whirLbMiicVdio4qvUfM5KAg6Ct8VwpYzGff3uctyCc) for theoretical direct-swap prices at the same block. 3) Telegram bot delivering hourly summaries: best/worst routed pairs, average price improvement, and 'would have been better direct' percentage. 4) Web dashboard with 24h rolling charts per token pair showing Jupiter efficiency score. 5) Alert system for when Jupiter routing degrades below a configurable threshold for specific pairs.
competitive_landscape: Birdeye and Jupiter's own UI show trade history but not route efficiency analysis. Step Finance provides portfolio tracking but no routing analytics. DexScreener shows prices but not routing path decomposition. The gap: nobody quantifies whether Jupiter's routing is actually optimal vs. direct AMM access — this is the first tool to score the aggregator itself.
timing_rationale: Jupiter processing 211,765 tx/hr (8.5x Raydium) means aggregator dependency is at an all-time high. The 9 new DeFi repos including DEX parsers and arbitrage bots show builders are already trying to understand Jupiter's transaction flow. This tool monetizes that curiosity before the parser ecosystem commoditizes it.

title: RouteLeech — Jupiter Bypass Router for Large Trades
description: A smart order router that sits alongside Jupiter but intelligently bypasses it for trades where direct AMM execution is cheaper. Queries Jupiter's Quote API (https://quote-api.jup.ag/v6) for the aggregated route, then independently checks Raydium CLMM, Orca Whirlpool, and Phoenix (PhoeNiXZ8ByJGLkxNfZRnkUfjvmuYqLR89jjFHGqdXY) limit order book for the same pair. If direct execution saves more than a configurable threshold (default 5bps), it routes directly, skipping Jupiter's platform fee. Built as a Rust CLI and Telegram bot using solana-sdk and anchor-client.
target_user: Solana DeFi whales and trading desks executing $50K+ swaps who lose significant value to Jupiter's routing on high-liquidity pairs. Pain point: Jupiter adds latency and fees for pairs where a single venue has sufficient depth. They'd switch because saving 5-15bps on large trades compounds to thousands per month.
mvp_scope: 1) Rust binary querying Jupiter Quote API and directly querying Raydium CLMM and Orca Whirlpool on-chain accounts for pool reserves and tick data. 2) Comparison engine that calculates slippage for Jupiter's proposed route vs. direct venue execution, accounting for priority fees and platform fees. 3) Transaction builder using solana-sdk that constructs and submits the optimal path (Jupiter or direct). 4) Telegram bot interface for submitting trades with configurable bypass threshold. 5) Trade log with CSV export showing savings per trade vs. naive Jupiter routing.
competitive_landscape: Jupiter itself is the incumbent. Prism and DFlow offer intent-based order flow but require protocol integration. No existing tool lets users conditionally bypass Jupiter when direct is cheaper — everyone assumes the aggregator is always best. The moat is the real-time comparison engine with multi-venue quoting.
timing_rationale: At 211,765 tx/hr, Jupiter processes enough volume that even small per-trade inefficiencies aggregate to massive value extraction. The 8.47x ratio over Raydium shows liquidity is concentrating, but that doesn't mean routing through Jupiter is always optimal — especially for high-liquidity pairs like SOL/USDC where a single Orca Whirlpool has sufficient depth.

title: JupFlow — Jupiter Transaction Stream Analytics API
description: A hosted API and WebSocket feed providing structured, real-time analytics on Jupiter v6 transaction flow. Ingests all Jupiter program instructions via Helius gRPC (Yellowstone), decodes them into structured swap events (token pair, route legs, input/output amounts, slippage, fees), and serves them through a REST API and WebSocket stream. Think 'Dune Analytics but real-time and Jupiter-specific.' Enables downstream builders (arbitrage bots, analytics dashboards, research) to consume Jupiter flow data without running their own parser infrastructure.
target_user: DeFi developers building on top of Jupiter's transaction flow — the 229 forkers of DeFi repos this month who are writing their own Jupiter parsers. Pain point: every team reinvents Jupiter instruction decoding, wastes days on Anchor IDL parsing edge cases. They'd switch because a clean API eliminates the parsing infrastructure burden.
mvp_scope: 1) Yellowstone gRPC subscriber filtering Jupiter v6 program transactions using Helius enhanced API. 2) Decoder service parsing Jupiter swap instructions into structured JSON (pair, route, amounts, slippage, timestamp, slot). 3) REST API with endpoints: /swaps (paginated history), /pairs/{base}/{quote} (pair-specific flow), /stats (hourly aggregates). 4) WebSocket feed for real-time swap events with optional pair filtering. 5) Rate-limited free tier (100 req/min) and paid tier ($49/mo unlimited) with API key management.
competitive_landscape: Helius provides raw transaction data but not Jupiter-decoded structured feeds. Shyft and Triton offer general Solana data but lack Jupiter-specific decoding. Birdeye has trade data but no programmatic API for raw Jupiter flow. The gap: structured, real-time, Jupiter-decoded transaction data as a service — the picks-and-shovels play for the Jupiter ecosystem.
timing_rationale: 9 new DeFi repos (269 stars, 229 forks) are building around Jupiter's transaction flow right now. The 229 forks specifically signal downstream builders who need this data. Selling parsed Jupiter data as infrastructure captures value from the ecosystem building atop the 211,765 tx/hr flow.

title: SandwichRadar — Real-Time JIT/MEV Attack Detection & Alerting
description: A monitoring service that detects JIT sandwich attacks on Solana AMMs in real-time by analyzing transaction ordering within slots. Uses Helius enhanced transaction API to identify the telltale pattern: attacker swap → victim swap → attacker reverse swap within the same slot, targeting Raydium CLMM (CAMMCzo5YL8w4VFF8KVHrK22GGUsp5VTaW7grrKgrWqK) and Orca Whirlpool (whirLbMiicVdio4qvUfM5KAg6Ct8VwpYzGff3uctyCc) pools. Provides a Telegram bot that alerts users when their wallets are sandwiched, a public dashboard showing MEV extraction rates per pool, and an API for dApps to integrate victim-detection into their UIs.
target_user: Solana DeFi traders who swap on AMMs and don't know they're being sandwiched. Secondary: dApp developers who want to display MEV risk warnings in their swap UIs. Pain point: sandwich attacks on Solana are invisible — unlike Ethereum's Flashbots Protect, there's no widely-used tool that even tells you it happened. They'd use this because knowledge is the first step toward protection.
mvp_scope: 1) Slot-level transaction analyzer that pulls ordered transactions per slot via Helius API and identifies sandwich triplets (frontrun → victim → backrun) on major AMM programs. 2) Telegram bot: users register wallets, get alerted within 30s when sandwiched, including attacker address, extracted value, and the pool. 3) Public dashboard showing real-time sandwich attack frequency, top attacker addresses, most-attacked pools, and total MEV extracted (24h/7d/30d). 4) REST API endpoint: given a transaction signature, returns whether it was part of a sandwich attack and the extraction amount. 5) Weekly email digest for registered users summarizing their MEV exposure.
competitive_landscape: Jito's block engine provides MEV redistribution but doesn't surface individual attack detection to users. The no_JIT repo (181 stars) provides protection at the protocol level but not user-facing detection. EigenPhi covers Ethereum MEV but not Solana. The gap: no Solana-specific tool tells individual users 'you just got sandwiched for $X' — this is the MEV awareness layer.
timing_rationale: The no_JIT repo hitting 181 stars as the most-starred new DeFi repo signals intense demand for MEV protection tooling. But protection without detection is blind — users first need to understand the problem's magnitude. Jito's 380 tx/hr stake pool activity shows MEV redistribution is live, but individual victim awareness is zero. This tool creates the demand signal that drives adoption of protection tools like no_JIT.

title: MEVShield Swap — Anti-Sandwich Swap Interface with Jito Bundle Submission
description: A swap frontend that protects users from JIT sandwich attacks by submitting transactions as Jito bundles (via jito-labs/jito-sdk) with tip to validators, ensuring atomic execution without frontrunning opportunity. Integrates Jupiter v6 Quote API for optimal routing but wraps the final transaction in a Jito bundle with a configurable tip (default: 0.001 SOL). The key insight from no_JIT: rather than modifying AMM programs, protect at the transaction submission layer. Also includes a 'private mempool' mode using Jito's Block Engine API for maximum protection on large swaps.
target_user: DeFi traders making swaps above $1K who are aware of sandwich attacks and willing to pay a small tip for protection. Pain point: Jupiter's default RPC submission exposes transactions to the public mempool where searchers can sandwich them. They'd switch from vanilla Jupiter because protection costs less than typical sandwich extraction (5-50bps vs. tip of ~0.001 SOL).
mvp_scope: 1) Web-based swap interface querying Jupiter v6 Quote API for routes, displaying quoted price and estimated sandwich risk based on pool liquidity depth. 2) Transaction builder that wraps Jupiter swap instructions in Jito bundle format using @jito-labs/jito-ts SDK with configurable tip amount. 3) Bundle submission via Jito Block Engine API (https://mainnet.block-engine.jito.wtf) with status tracking and retry logic. 4) Before/after comparison showing the user: 'Normal swap slippage: X%, Protected swap cost: Y SOL tip, Net savings: Z%'. 5) Wallet adapter integration (Phantom, Solflare, Backpack) via @solana/wallet-adapter.
competitive_landscape: Jupiter's default UI submits via standard RPC — no MEV protection. bloXroute and Jito offer bundle APIs but no user-facing swap interface. MEV Blocker on Ethereum (Flashbots Protect) proved the model works but doesn't exist on Solana. The gap: the simplest possible 'protected swap' UX that requires zero technical knowledge — just swap with a checkbox for 'MEV Protection: On'.
timing_rationale: no_JIT's 181 stars prove demand for MEV protection. 229 forks across DeFi repos show builders are adapting protection tools. Jito's 380 tx/hr stake pool validates that the MEV-aware infrastructure exists. But there's no user-facing product that wraps it all in a simple swap UX — the integration gap between raw infra and end users is wide open this week.

title: MEV Tax Calculator — Cumulative Sandwich Loss Tracker
description: A wallet analysis tool that scans a user's complete Solana swap history, identifies every transaction that was part of a sandwich attack, and calculates the total cumulative MEV extracted from their wallet. Uses Helius parsed transaction history API to pull all DEX swaps, then cross-references with slot-level transaction ordering to detect sandwich patterns around each swap. Outputs a 'MEV Tax Report' showing total USD lost to sandwiching, worst individual attacks, most-exploited pools, and a comparison against what Jito bundle tips would have cost for protection.
target_user: Solana DeFi users who trade regularly but have no idea how much value they've lost to MEV extraction. Pain point: the cost of sandwiching is invisible — it looks like normal slippage. They'd use this because seeing '$2,847 lost to sandwiches in the last 90 days' is the most powerful possible sales pitch for MEV protection tools.
mvp_scope: 1) Wallet history scanner using Helius parsed transactions API to extract all DEX swap transactions (Jupiter, Raydium, Orca, Phoenix). 2) Sandwich detection engine analyzing slot-level transaction ordering around each user swap to identify frontrun/backrun pairs. 3) Loss calculation: for each sandwiched swap, compute the price impact attributable to the attacker's frontrun vs. natural slippage. 4) Web report page: total MEV lost (USD), timeline chart, per-pool breakdown, worst attacks, and 'if you'd used Jito bundles, you'd have saved $X at a cost of $Y in tips.' 5) Shareable report URL with Twitter card preview for viral distribution.
competitive_landscape: EigenPhi does this for Ethereum but not Solana. Solscan and Solana FM show transaction history but don't identify sandwiches. No existing Solana tool provides cumulative MEV loss accounting per wallet. The moat is the sandwich detection algorithm tuned for Solana's slot-based ordering (not block-based like Ethereum).
timing_rationale: With no_JIT at 181 stars, the MEV protection narrative is hot but abstract — users know sandwiching is bad but don't know their personal exposure. This tool makes it concrete and personal. The shareable report creates viral distribution: 'I lost $X to Solana sandwiches' posts drive awareness that feeds demand for protection tooling.

title: JitoYield — jitoSOL Yield Optimizer Across Lending Markets
description: An automated yield optimizer that takes jitoSOL (J1toso1uCk3RLmjorhTtrVwY9HJ7X8V9yYac6Y7kGCPn — Jito's liquid staking token) and deploys it across Solana lending markets — Kamino (KLend2g3cP87ber8kVGMPCvjHKfLNTqV1TYbmwwy5xXk), MarginFi, and Solend — to maximize total yield (staking rewards + MEV share + lending APY). Monitors rates across all three protocols via on-chain account reads, rebalances weekly, and compounds jitoSOL's native MEV yield with the highest available lending rate. The key insight: jitoSOL's 40:1 activity dominance over mSOL means it's becoming the default LST collateral — optimize yield specifically for the winning token.
target_user: SOL holders with 100+ SOL who currently just stake via Jito but aren't deploying their jitoSOL into lending markets. Pain point: jitoSOL holders leave 3-5% additional APY on the table because manually monitoring and moving across Kamino/MarginFi/Solend is tedious. They'd switch from bare jitoSOL staking because this tool automates the yield stack.
mvp_scope: 1) Rate monitor polling Kamino KLend, MarginFi, and Solend jitoSOL supply rates every 5 minutes via on-chain account deserialization. 2) Yield comparison dashboard showing current rates across all three protocols, historical APY charts, and the optimal allocation. 3) One-click deposit flow: user deposits SOL → auto-stakes via Jito Stake Pool (Jito4APyf641qhVPf3Y6kGYP5QMNT5branch) → deposits jitoSOL into highest-yield lending market. 4) Weekly auto-rebalance: if a higher-yield market opens up by >50bps, migrates jitoSOL between lending protocols. 5) Telegram bot with yield alerts and rebalance notifications.
competitive_landscape: Kamino has auto-compounding vaults but only for their own protocol. Tulip Protocol offers yield aggregation but hasn't updated for jitoSOL dominance. Francium focuses on leveraged yield, not LST optimization. The gap: no tool specifically optimizes jitoSOL yield across multiple lending markets — everyone optimizes for generic tokens, not the winning LST specifically.
timing_rationale: Jito's 40:1 activity ratio over Marinade is the clearest signal: jitoSOL is winning the LST race. $24.8B in liquid staking TVL and $5.5B in lending TVL means the jitoSOL-to-lending pipeline is enormous. Building the yield optimizer for the winning LST now captures the flywheel as more stakers shift from mSOL to jitoSOL.

title: StakeShift — Marinade-to-Jito Migration Assistant
description: A one-click migration tool that unstakes mSOL (mSoLzYCxHdYgdzU16g5QSh3i5K3z3KZK7ytfqcJm7So — Marinade's LST) and restakes into jitoSOL, handling the entire flow: mSOL → SOL unstaking (or instant liquid unstake via Marinade), SOL → jitoSOL staking via Jito Stake Pool, with real-time yield comparison showing the APY differential. Includes a 'migration calculator' showing projected additional yield from MEV sharing over 30/90/365 days.
target_user: Current Marinade mSOL holders who see the writing on the wall (40:1 Jito activity ratio) but haven't migrated due to inertia and the multi-step unstake-restake friction. Pain point: migrating from mSOL to jitoSOL requires multiple transactions across two protocols, with a potential unstaking delay. They'd use this because it reduces a 15-minute, 4-transaction process to one click.
mvp_scope: 1) Migration calculator: input mSOL amount, see projected jitoSOL yield vs. current mSOL yield (staking + MEV share difference), net gain over 30/90/365 days. 2) Instant migration path: mSOL → SOL via Marinade instant unstake (if available) or Jupiter swap, then SOL → jitoSOL via Jito Stake Pool, bundled as a single transaction. 3) Delayed migration path: if instant unstake has poor rates, queue Marinade delayed unstake and auto-stake to Jito when SOL arrives. 4) Web interface with wallet connection showing current mSOL balance, migration options, and yield comparison. 5) Migration tracker: after initiating, shows progress, estimated completion, and cumulative yield difference since migration.
competitive_landscape: Neither Jito nor Marinade provides a cross-protocol migration tool. Jupiter can swap mSOL → jitoSOL but doesn't show yield comparison or optimize the migration path. Sanctum provides LST liquidity but doesn't market migration specifically. The gap: a purpose-built migration tool with yield comparison that makes the Marinade → Jito switch a no-brainer.
timing_rationale: The 40:1 Jito-to-Marinade activity ratio is accelerating — this is a migration event in progress. Every day mSOL holders don't switch, they lose the MEV yield differential. Building the migration tool now captures the largest wave of LST switching in Solana history. The $24.8B liquid staking TVL means even capturing 1% of migrators is a significant user base.

title: LST Dominance Tracker — Liquid Staking Market Share Dashboard
description: A real-time dashboard tracking the liquid staking wars on Solana: jitoSOL vs. mSOL vs. bSOL (BlazeStake) vs. all other LSTs. Tracks on-chain metrics — stake pool deposits/withdrawals, TVL, DeFi integrations (lending deposits, LP positions), validator set overlap — and visualizes the shift in market share over time. Ingests data from Jito Stake Pool, Marinade (MarBmsSgKXdrN1egZf5sqe1TMai9K1rChYNDJgjq7aD), and BlazeStake programs directly via Solana RPC.
target_user: DeFi researchers, fund managers, and protocol teams who need to understand LST market dynamics for allocation decisions. Pain point: no single dashboard shows the LST competitive landscape with on-chain data — you have to check each protocol's UI separately and manually compare. They'd use this because LST dominance directly impacts DeFi composability decisions.
mvp_scope: 1) On-chain data ingestion from Jito, Marinade, and BlazeStake stake pool programs, tracking total staked SOL, deposit/withdrawal flows, and active staker counts. 2) DeFi integration tracker: how much of each LST is deposited in Kamino, MarginFi, Solend, Orca, and Raydium — shows which LST has the deepest DeFi utility. 3) Market share visualization: pie chart (current), area chart (over time), and flow diagram (net migrations between LSTs). 4) Weekly report auto-generated and posted to Twitter via API, establishing the dashboard as the authoritative source for LST market data. 5) Embeddable widgets for other dashboards and research platforms.
competitive_landscape: DefiLlama shows TVL per protocol but doesn't break down LST market share dynamics or DeFi integration depth. Dune has Solana dashboards but LST-specific ones are stale or incomplete. Flipside covers Solana but not LST-specific flows. The gap: a purpose-built LST competitive intelligence dashboard that treats the LST market as its own category rather than a subcategory of staking.
timing_rationale: The Jito-Marinade divergence (40:1 ratio, accelerating trend) is the biggest structural shift in Solana liquid staking. Fund managers and protocol teams need this data to make allocation decisions. Building the authoritative dashboard now — while the shift is in progress — establishes first-mover advantage as the go-to LST intelligence source.

title: ETFFlow — Solana ETF Filing Tracker & SOL Supply Impact Model
description: A dashboard tracking all 16 U.S. Solana Spot ETF filings in real-time — approval status, fee structures, ticker symbols, S-1 amendments, SEC comment letters — combined with a supply impact model that projects how much SOL each ETF would absorb from circulating supply based on AUM estimates. Scrapes SEC EDGAR for filing updates, cross-references with the 567.8M circulating SOL (91.5% of total supply), and models scenarios: 'If Solana ETFs capture 10% of Bitcoin ETF AUM ($X), that's Y% of circulating SOL locked up.'
target_user: Institutional investors and family offices evaluating Solana ETF exposure who need a single source of truth for all 16 filings. Secondary: crypto-native traders who want to front-run ETF approval catalysts. Pain point: tracking 16 separate SEC filings across multiple issuers is manual and error-prone — Bloomberg terminal doesn't cover crypto ETF filings well. They'd use this because it's the only Solana-specific ETF intelligence product.
mvp_scope: 1) SEC EDGAR scraper monitoring all 16 Solana ETF filings (S-1s, 19b-4s, comment letters, amendments) with Telegram/email alerts on any new filing. 2) ETF comparison table: issuer, ticker, fee, custodian, staking yield pass-through (yes/no), filing date, current status. 3) Supply impact model: given AUM scenarios (1%, 5%, 10% of BTC ETF flows), calculate SOL absorbed from circulating supply (567.8M) and projected price impact using on-chain liquidity data. 4) Timeline visualization showing each filing's progression through SEC review stages with estimated decision dates. 5) Weekly newsletter summarizing ETF filing activity, regulatory signals, and supply model updates.
competitive_landscape: Bloomberg tracks ETF filings but without Solana-specific supply modeling. The Block and CoinDesk cover ETF news editorially but don't maintain a structured tracker. Nansen and Messari provide institutional-grade analytics but haven't built a Solana ETF-specific product. The gap: no product combines ETF filing tracking with on-chain supply impact modeling specifically for Solana.
timing_rationale: 16 ETF filings is an unprecedented concentration of institutional attention on Solana. The 91.5% circulating supply ratio means ETF demand directly impacts available SOL — this isn't like Bitcoin where large portions are dormant. Solana's #2 TVL ranking ($6.37B) validates the institutional thesis. Building the tracker now, before any approval, captures the entire pre-approval attention window.

title: StakeYield ETF — Solana Staking Yield Comparison for ETF Investors
description: A tool specifically designed for institutional investors comparing Solana ETF products by their staking yield pass-through mechanics. Not all 16 ETF filings handle staking rewards the same way — some pass through yield, others don't, and the difference in total return is enormous given SOL's ~7% staking APY. This tool models total return for each ETF product including staking yield, MEV (via Jito), management fees, and tracking error, using on-chain staking data from the Solana Foundation Delegation Program and Jito stake pool.
target_user: Financial advisors and institutional allocators who need to compare Solana ETF products on total return, not just management fee. Pain point: ETF comparison tools (ETF.com, Morningstar) don't understand Solana staking yield mechanics — they'll compare fees but miss the 7% APY difference between staking and non-staking products. They'd use this because it's the only tool that models crypto-native yield in ETF wrapper terms.
mvp_scope: 1) ETF product comparison matrix: for each of the 16 filings, extract whether staking yield is passed through, management fee, custodian, and staking infrastructure partner. 2) Total return model: given SOL price scenarios and staking APY (pulled from on-chain epoch rewards data), project 1-year total return for each ETF including/excluding staking yield minus fees. 3) Jito MEV yield layer: model the additional yield if the ETF uses Jito-based staking vs. traditional delegation, using live Jito MEV data from on-chain. 4) Comparison calculator: input investment amount and time horizon, see projected returns across all ETF products side-by-side. 5) PDF report generator for institutional use with disclaimers and methodology notes.
competitive_landscape: Traditional ETF comparison tools (ETF.com, Morningstar) don't model staking yield. Crypto research firms (Messari, Delphi) provide general staking yield data but don't map it to specific ETF products. No existing tool bridges crypto-native staking mechanics with institutional ETF analysis. The moat is the mapping between on-chain staking data and ETF product structures.
timing_rationale: With 16 ETF filings active, institutions will soon need to choose between products. The differentiator won't be management fees (they'll converge) — it'll be staking yield pass-through. Building this comparison tool before approvals positions it as the go-to resource during the actual product selection phase. Solana Foundation Delegation Program coverage confirms staking infrastructure is being discussed at the institutional level.

title: SOLSupplyWatch — Circulating Supply Monitor with ETF Demand Overlay
description: A real-time SOL circulating supply monitor that tracks the 567.8M circulating SOL across categories: staked (validator + liquid staking), DeFi-locked, exchange balances, and freely circulating. Overlays projected ETF demand absorption from the 16 filed ETFs using AUM estimates. The key insight: with 91.5% already circulating and large portions locked in staking ($24.8B) and DeFi ($6.37B TVL), the freely available SOL for ETF custody is much smaller than the headline circulating number suggests.
target_user: Crypto-native traders and macro funds modeling SOL supply dynamics ahead of ETF approvals. Pain point: the '567.8M circulating' number is misleading — much of it is locked in staking, DeFi, or dormant. No tool shows the actual 'available float' that ETFs would compete for. They'd use this for trade sizing and timing around ETF catalysts.
mvp_scope: 1) Real-time SOL supply decomposition: total supply, staked (via validators and LST pools), DeFi-locked (querying major protocol TVLs), exchange balances (via exchange wallet labeling from Arkham/Nansen-style heuristics), and true free float. 2) ETF demand scenario modeler: input assumptions about ETF AUM capture rates, output projected SOL demand vs. available float. 3) Supply change alerts: notify when significant SOL moves between categories (large unstaking events, DeFi withdrawals, exchange inflows). 4) Historical supply decomposition chart showing how the ratio between staked/DeFi/exchange/free has shifted over time. 5) API endpoint for programmatic access to supply decomposition data.
competitive_landscape: Solana Beach shows basic supply stats but not decomposed by usage category. Messari provides supply data but not real-time decomposition with DeFi-locked amounts. CoinGecko/CoinMarketCap show circulating supply but not the nuanced breakdown. The gap: no tool answers 'how much SOL is actually available for ETF custody?' with real-time on-chain data.
timing_rationale: 16 ETF filings + 91.5% circulating supply + $24.8B in liquid staking + $6.37B DeFi TVL = the supply squeeze thesis needs a data product. Building this before ETF approvals establishes it as the reference source for the supply impact narrative that will dominate crypto media coverage.

title: AgentLedger — On-Chain AI Agent Activity Dashboard
description: A real-time dashboard tracking autonomous AI agent activity on Solana by monitoring known agent wallet addresses and program interactions. Identifies and labels AI agent transactions by cross-referencing SIGNIA-registered agents, known AI trading bot addresses (from CloddsBot and similar repos), and heuristic detection (high-frequency, programmatic transaction patterns on Jupiter/Raydium). Shows what agents are doing on-chain: trading frequency, PnL, protocol interactions, gas spending, and failure rates. Built on Helius enhanced transaction API with Yellowstone gRPC for real-time streaming.
target_user: Crypto researchers and VCs evaluating the AI agent thesis who need empirical data on whether agents are actually transacting on-chain or if it's pure narrative. Secondary: agent developers who want to benchmark their agent's on-chain behavior against peers. Pain point: the AI agent narrative has 222 stars but only 21 forks — spectators need data to decide if this is real. They'd use this because it's the first empirical measurement of AI agent on-chain activity.
mvp_scope: 1) Agent registry: manually curated list of known AI agent wallets from SIGNIA, CloddsBot, and other identified agent frameworks, plus heuristic detection for unlabeled agents (high-frequency, programmatic patterns). 2) Transaction tracker: ingest all transactions from registered agent wallets via Helius API, categorize by type (swap, stake, transfer, program interaction). 3) Dashboard with metrics: total agent transactions/day, agent share of Jupiter volume, top agents by activity and PnL, protocol distribution (which programs agents use most). 4) Agent profile pages: per-agent view showing transaction history, PnL curve, strategy classification (arb, market-making, trend-following), and gas efficiency. 5) Weekly 'State of Solana AI Agents' report auto-generated from dashboard data.
competitive_landscape: Arkham Intelligence labels wallets but doesn't specifically track AI agents. Nansen has smart money tracking but not AI agent classification. No existing tool distinguishes AI agent transactions from human or bot transactions on Solana. The moat is the agent identification heuristics and the curated registry — both improve with network effects.
timing_rationale: SIGNIA at 207 stars (93% of AI agent category stars) shows the narrative is concentrated but speculative — the 10.6x star-to-fork ratio confirms more spectators than builders. This dashboard converts narrative attention into empirical data, answering the key question: are AI agents actually doing anything on Solana? The 1,179 non-vote TPS provides the throughput headroom that makes agent activity feasible.

title: AgentForge — Solana AI Agent Deployment Kit with SIGNIA Integration
description: A Rust-based framework and CLI tool for deploying AI agents that execute on-chain actions on Solana, with built-in SIGNIA identity registration and Jupiter v6 swap execution. Reduces the 'hello world' for a Solana AI agent from weeks of integration work to a single CLI command. The agent template includes: wallet management, Jupiter swap execution, Jito bundle submission for MEV protection, SIGNIA identity attestation, and a configurable strategy interface. Think 'create-solana-dapp but for AI agents.'
target_user: AI/ML developers who want to deploy agents on Solana but are blocked by the complexity of Solana program interaction, wallet management, and transaction construction. Pain point: building a Solana-native agent from scratch requires deep Solana knowledge (transaction building, CPI, PDAs) that AI developers don't have. They'd use this because it abstracts Solana complexity behind an agent-friendly API.
mvp_scope: 1) Rust crate (solana-agent-kit) providing high-level agent primitives: create wallet, check balances, swap tokens (via Jupiter), stake SOL (via Jito), submit protected transactions (via Jito bundles). 2) CLI tool: `agent-forge init` scaffolds a new agent project with configurable strategy template, wallet setup, and SIGNIA registration. 3) Strategy interface trait: implement `fn decide(&self, market_state: &State) -> Vec<Action>` and the framework handles transaction construction, signing, submission, and error handling. 4) Example agents: simple rebalancer (maintains target allocation across 3 tokens), DCA bot (dollar-cost averages into SOL using Jupiter DCA program JUPyiwrYJFskUPiHa7hkeR8VUtAeFoSYbKedZNsDvCN), momentum trader (buys/sells based on price EMA crossover). 5) Deployment guide for running on a VPS with systemd, including monitoring and alerting setup.
competitive_landscape: SIGNIA provides identity but not execution infrastructure. ElizaOS and ai16z frameworks are EVM-focused, not Solana-native. Solana's official SDKs (solana-sdk, anchor) are too low-level for agent developers. The gap: no opinionated, agent-first framework for Solana that handles the entire lifecycle from wallet creation to on-chain execution.
timing_rationale: The 10.6x star-to-fork ratio on AI agent repos signals a builder bottleneck — people want to build agents but can't. SIGNIA's 207 stars provide the identity layer. Jupiter's 211,765 tx/hr and Jito's bundle infrastructure provide the execution layer. This kit connects the dots: identity (SIGNIA) + execution (Jupiter/Jito) + framework (AgentForge) = the missing middle layer.

title: x402Pay — HTTP 402 Micropayment Gateway for AI Agent Services
description: A micropayment gateway implementing the x402 protocol standard for AI agent-to-agent and agent-to-service payments on Solana. When an AI agent requests a paid API endpoint (data feed, computation, model inference), the server returns HTTP 402 with a Solana payment instruction. The agent's wallet automatically pays (SPL token transfer via Token Program TokenkegQfeZyiNwAJbNbGKPFXCWuBvf9Ss623VQ5DA) and retries the request with a payment proof header. Enables the 'machine-payable web' where AI agents can autonomously purchase services without human intervention.
target_user: AI agent developers who want their agents to be able to pay for API services (data, compute, model access) autonomously. Secondary: API providers who want to monetize machine-to-machine traffic without API key management. Pain point: current AI agents can't pay for services — they need pre-provisioned API keys. x402 makes payment native to HTTP. They'd adopt this because it unlocks agent autonomy for any paid service.
mvp_scope: 1) Rust middleware crate (x402-solana) for Actix-web/Axum that adds x402 payment gating to any API endpoint: returns 402 with Solana payment instruction on unauthorized requests, verifies on-chain payment confirmation on retry. 2) Agent-side payment client: given an HTTP 402 response, automatically constructs and submits the Solana payment transaction, waits for confirmation, and retries with proof. 3) Payment verification: confirms SPL token transfer on-chain via Solana RPC before granting access, with replay protection (each payment receipt is single-use). 4) Example integration: a paid price-feed API that charges 0.001 USDC per request via x402, with an example AI agent that consumes it. 5) NPM/crates.io packages for both server middleware and client SDK.
competitive_landscape: x402-deploy has 9 stars — very early. Stripe and traditional payment gateways don't support machine-to-machine micropayments. Lightning Network has similar goals but not on Solana. Sphere and Helio handle Solana payments but for human-initiated flows, not machine-to-machine. The gap: no production-ready x402 implementation exists on Solana — this is greenfield infrastructure for the agent economy.
timing_rationale: x402-deploy's appearance in trending repos signals the protocol standard is being discussed. SIGNIA provides agent identity. The missing piece is agent-native payments. Solana's sub-second finality and sub-cent transaction costs make it the ideal chain for micropayments — the 1,179 non-vote TPS shows capacity exists. Building x402 infrastructure now positions for the agent economy before it materializes.

title: ValidatorDuel — Firedancer vs. Agave Performance Comparison Dashboard
description: A real-time dashboard comparing Firedancer and Agave (formerly Solana Labs) validator client performance metrics side-by-side: block production time, vote latency, skip rate, memory usage, and transaction processing throughput. Pulls data from the Solana validator gossip network and on-chain leader schedule to identify which client each validator runs, then aggregates performance metrics per client. The first tool to answer: 'Is Firedancer actually faster in production?' with empirical data rather than benchmarks.
target_user: Solana validators deciding whether to switch from Agave to Firedancer, and stake pool operators (Jito, Marinade, BlazeStake) who need to evaluate client performance for delegation decisions. Pain point: Firedancer has 1,396 stars and massive hype but no public production performance comparison exists — validators are flying blind. They'd use this because client choice directly impacts staking rewards.
mvp_scope: 1) Validator client classifier: identify which client each validator runs by analyzing gossip protocol version strings and known Firedancer/Agave signatures via Solana RPC getClusterNodes. 2) Performance metrics collector: for each validator, track block production time, vote latency (time from slot to vote transaction), skip rate, and delinquency using getVoteAccounts and getBlockProduction RPC calls. 3) Dashboard with side-by-side comparison: Firedancer validators (aggregate) vs. Agave validators (aggregate) on all metrics, with statistical significance indicators. 4) Individual validator lookup: enter a validator identity, see which client it runs and how it compares to same-client peers and cross-client average. 5) Weekly report: 'State of Solana Client Diversity' showing Firedancer adoption rate, performance delta, and network health implications.
competitive_landscape: Validators.app tracks validator performance but doesn't break down by client software. Stakewiz focuses on delegation recommendations without client analysis. Solana Beach shows validator stats but no client classification. The gap: no tool segments validator performance by client software — this is critical intelligence as Solana transitions to a multi-client network.
timing_rationale: Firedancer at 1,396 stars + Agave 3.1 updates = both clients advancing simultaneously. Epoch 925 at 27.2% progress means validators are actively running and producing data. The 3,175 TPS (1,179 non-vote) provides enough throughput to generate meaningful performance comparisons. Building this during the dual-client transition captures the validator decision-making window.

title: ClientWatch — Solana Network Client Diversity Monitor
description: A network health dashboard focused exclusively on client diversity — tracking the ratio of Firedancer to Agave nodes, geographic distribution per client, stake weight per client, and the 'diversity score' (how close the network is to the ideal 50/50 split that prevents single-client failure from halting the chain). Inspired by Ethereum's clientdiversity.org but built for Solana's specific dual-client architecture. Alerts when client diversity drops below safety thresholds.
target_user: Solana Foundation, core developers, and large stakers who need to monitor network resilience. Pain point: Ethereum learned the hard way (Prysm dominance) that client diversity needs active monitoring — Solana doesn't have an equivalent tool. They'd use this because client diversity is a systemic risk factor that affects everyone's staking returns.
mvp_scope: 1) Client identification engine: classify all active validators by client type (Firedancer/Agave/other) using gossip version analysis and known validator operator surveys. 2) Diversity metrics: compute client distribution by node count, by stake weight, and by geographic region (using IP geolocation of gossip addresses). 3) Safety threshold alerts: if any single client exceeds 66% of stake weight (the threshold for unilateral finality), alert via Telegram and Twitter. 4) Historical trend chart showing client diversity over time (daily snapshots). 5) Validator operator outreach: for validators running the majority client, show a 'please consider switching' prompt with migration guides.
competitive_landscape: Ethereum's clientdiversity.org is the model but doesn't cover Solana. Solana has no equivalent. Validators.app and Stakewiz track performance but not client diversity as a network health metric. The gap: the Solana ecosystem lacks a dedicated client diversity monitoring tool despite actively deploying a second client (Firedancer).
timing_rationale: Firedancer's 1,396 stars and Agave 3.1 updates mean the multi-client era is arriving. The 487B cumulative transactions and 3,175 TPS show a production network where client bugs have real consequences. Building the diversity monitor now — before Firedancer reaches significant adoption — establishes the baseline and creates the accountability tool for the transition.

title: EpochPulse — Solana Epoch Analytics and Staking Reward Predictor
description: A dashboard providing deep analytics on Solana epoch progression and staking reward estimation. Tracks epoch 925 progress (currently 27.2%), predicts epoch boundary timing, estimates staking rewards per validator based on actual performance this epoch (blocks produced, votes cast, skip rate), and provides early alerts for validators at risk of reduced rewards. Integrates Jito MEV reward data for jitoSOL holders to see their total expected yield (base staking + MEV) for the current epoch.
target_user: Solana stakers (both direct delegators and LST holders) who want to understand their expected rewards before epoch boundary, and validators who want to monitor their in-epoch performance. Pain point: staking rewards are only visible after epoch completion — no tool predicts mid-epoch. They'd use this because reward visibility drives better delegation decisions.
mvp_scope: 1) Epoch progress tracker: current epoch number, slot progress, estimated time to epoch boundary, slots remaining, using getEpochInfo RPC. 2) Validator performance scorer: for each validator in current epoch, compute blocks produced vs. expected (from leader schedule), vote participation rate, and projected reward. 3) Staking reward estimator: given a stake account or LST balance, project expected reward for current epoch based on validator performance so far. 4) Jito MEV overlay: for jitoSOL holders, add estimated MEV reward component from Jito's tip distribution program to total yield projection. 5) Alert system: notify delegators if their chosen validator's performance drops below network median mid-epoch.
competitive_landscape: Stakewiz shows historical rewards but not mid-epoch predictions. Solana Beach shows epoch progress but not reward estimation. Marinade's dashboard is protocol-specific. The gap: no tool provides mid-epoch reward prediction combining base staking + MEV yields with validator-specific performance data.
timing_rationale: Epoch 925 at 27.2% progress means there's live data to analyze right now. The 3,175 TPS and 487B cumulative transactions show a mature network where staking reward optimization matters at scale. Jito's dominance (380 tx/hr) means MEV yield is a significant component that existing tools don't integrate into reward predictions.

title: LaunchGuard — Memecoin Launch Risk Scanner
description: A real-time risk scanner for new token launches on Solana that analyzes Metaplex Token Metadata (metaqbxxUerdq28cj1RbAWkYQm3ybzjb6a8bt518x1s) registrations and provides instant risk scores before users ape in. Checks: mint authority revoked (can they mint more?), freeze authority revoked (can they freeze your tokens?), LP locked (is liquidity permanent?), holder concentration (whale risk), metadata mutability (can they change the token name/image?), and deployer wallet history (has this wallet rugged before?). Built as a Telegram bot and browser extension that intercepts Birdeye/DexScreener links with risk overlays.
target_user: Retail memecoin traders who get rugged repeatedly because they don't know how to check on-chain token safety. Pain point: checking mint authority, freeze authority, LP locks, and holder distribution requires reading raw Solana account data — most traders can't do this. They'd use this because a 5-second risk scan before buying saves them from rugs.
mvp_scope: 1) Token analyzer engine: given a token mint address, query Metaplex Token Metadata, SPL Token program (TokenkegQfeZyiNwAJbNbGKPFXCWuBvf9Ss623VQ5DA), and associated accounts to extract mint authority, freeze authority, metadata update authority, total supply, and holder distribution. 2) LP analysis: check if Raydium/Orca LP tokens are locked or burnable by querying pool accounts and LP token holder distribution. 3) Deployer history: trace the deployer wallet's previous token launches using Helius transaction history — flag if previous tokens went to zero. 4) Telegram bot: paste a token address, get instant risk score (1-10) with breakdown of each risk factor. 5) Risk alert feed: monitor new Metaplex Token Metadata registrations (4,176 tx/hr), auto-scan, and publish high-risk tokens to a public Telegram channel as warnings.
competitive_landscape: RugCheck.xyz exists but has limited Solana coverage and slow updates. Birdeye shows some token info but not comprehensive risk scoring. GoPlus Security covers multichain but Solana analysis is shallow. The gap: no tool specifically monitors the 4,176 tx/hr Metaplex Token Metadata firehose in real-time with instant risk scoring — the current tools are reactive, not proactive.
timing_rationale: Metaplex processing 4,176 tx/hr (149x Tensor's 28 tx/hr) means token creation vastly outpaces legitimate trading activity — consistent with a high-churn launch economy where most tokens are pump-and-dumps. fdv.lol at 93 stars shows demand for memecoin radar tools. Building the safety layer for this launch volume captures the largest possible user base: everyone trading memecoins.

title: MeteoraBundleBot — Automated Meteora DBC Launch Bundler
description: A Telegram bot and CLI tool that automates the Meteora Dynamic Bonding Curve (DBC) token launch process, including LP position creation, initial buy bundling, and anti-sniper configuration. Based on the Meteora-DBC-Bagsapp-Bundler pattern (43 stars) but with added safety features: configurable launch parameters, simulated launch preview (dry run showing expected price curve), and automatic LP lock. Targets launch creators who want professional-grade launch mechanics without writing code.
target_user: Token launchers and memecoin creators who want to use Meteora's DBC for a fair launch but lack the technical skills to configure bundling, LP locking, and anti-sniper measures. Pain point: the Meteora-DBC-Bagsapp-Bundler exists as a repo but requires developer setup — no turnkey solution exists. They'd use this because a Telegram bot is infinitely more accessible than cloning a GitHub repo.
mvp_scope: 1) Telegram bot interface: guided token launch wizard — input token name, supply, initial price, LP lock duration, anti-sniper delay, and initial buy amounts. 2) Launch simulation: before executing, show the projected bonding curve, expected price at various buy volumes, and LP position preview. 3) Bundled execution: create token (via SPL Token), register metadata (via Metaplex), create Meteora DBC pool, lock LP, and execute initial buys — all bundled via Jito for atomicity. 4) Post-launch dashboard: track price, volume, holder count, and LP status for launched tokens. 5) Revenue model: 0.5 SOL per launch fee, with premium tier ($5 SOL/month) for advanced features like scheduled launches and multi-wallet bundling.
competitive_landscape: Meteora-DBC-Bagsapp-Bundler (43 stars) is open-source but requires technical setup. pump.fun and pumpdev.io (20 stars) offer launch platforms but on their own bonding curves, not Meteora. The gap: no turnkey, non-technical interface exists for Meteora DBC launches — this captures the launchers who prefer Meteora's mechanics but can't code.
timing_rationale: The Meteora bundler repo at 43 stars shows active demand. Metaplex at 4,176 tx/hr confirms the launch economy is booming. fdv.lol at 93 stars validates that memecoin tooling has market demand. Building the user-friendly interface for Meteora DBC launches captures the gap between open-source repos and non-technical launchers.

title: TokenRadar — Real-Time New Token Launch Feed with Smart Filters
description: A real-time feed of every new token created on Solana, filtered and scored by configurable criteria: initial liquidity depth, LP lock status, deployer wallet reputation, holder distribution at launch, social media presence (Twitter account linked in metadata), and metadata completeness. Think fdv.lol (93 stars, 'BLAZING-FAST memecoin radar') but with safety-first filtering that helps traders find legitimate launches among the noise of the 4,176 Metaplex tx/hr firehose.
target_user: Memecoin traders who want to find new launches early but are overwhelmed by the volume (4,176 metadata registrations/hr) and can't distinguish legitimate projects from rugs. Pain point: existing radar tools show everything without quality filtering — finding good launches is like drinking from a firehose. They'd switch from raw fdv.lol-style feeds because smart filtering saves time and reduces rug risk.
mvp_scope: 1) Metaplex Token Metadata program listener via Helius webhooks, capturing every new token registration in real-time. 2) Instant scoring engine: for each new token, compute a quality score (0-100) based on mint authority status, freeze authority, initial LP size, LP lock, deployer history, and metadata completeness. 3) Configurable filter presets: 'Safe Only' (score > 70, LP locked, authorities revoked), 'Degen' (score > 30, any LP), 'Whale Watch' (large initial LP only). 4) Multi-channel delivery: Telegram bot with filter subscription, web feed with real-time updates, Discord webhook integration. 5) Premium tier: push notifications within 10 seconds of launch (free tier: 60-second delay), historical launch data API, custom filter rules.
competitive_landscape: fdv.lol (93 stars) provides speed but not safety scoring. Birdeye new listings are delayed and lack risk metrics. DEXScreener shows new pairs but doesn't score token safety. The gap: combining the speed of fdv.lol with the safety analysis of RugCheck into a single real-time feed — nobody does both fast AND safe.
timing_rationale: 4,176 Metaplex tx/hr means ~100K new tokens per day — the signal-to-noise ratio is atrocious and getting worse. fdv.lol's 93 stars prove demand for speed. The 149:1 Metaplex-to-Tensor ratio confirms most tokens never develop secondary markets — they're created and abandoned. A filtered feed that separates signal from noise becomes more valuable as launch volume increases.

title: SnipeShield — Anti-Sniper Bot for Token Launches
description: A tool for token launchers that protects their launches from sniper bots by implementing configurable anti-sniper mechanics: delayed trading activation (first N blocks after pool creation reject non-whitelisted buys), max buy limits per wallet in the first minute, and honeypot-style traps that identify and blacklist known sniper wallets. Integrates with Raydium CLMM and Meteora DBC pool creation to inject anti-sniper guards at the AMM level. Uses Jito bundle submission to ensure launch transactions are atomic and not frontrunnable.
target_user: Token creators who want a fair launch where community members can buy before sniper bots extract all the initial value. Pain point: every Solana token launch gets sniped within milliseconds by bots that frontrun retail buyers, concentrating tokens in bot wallets that then dump. They'd use this because anti-sniper protection directly increases community goodwill and token distribution fairness.
mvp_scope: 1) Launch protection wrapper: wraps Raydium CLMM or Meteora DBC pool creation in a Jito bundle with configurable anti-sniper parameters (trading delay, max buy per wallet, whitelist). 2) Sniper detection: monitor mempool (via Jito Block Engine) for transactions targeting the new pool before trading is officially open, log and blacklist detected sniper wallets. 3) Whitelist management: launcher provides a list of community wallets that can buy during the protection window. 4) Post-launch report: show which wallets tried to snipe, how many were blocked, and the resulting token distribution comparison (with vs. without protection). 5) Telegram bot interface for configuring and monitoring launch protection in real-time.
competitive_landscape: pump.fun has built-in anti-sniper mechanics but only for their own bonding curve. No tool provides anti-sniper protection for Raydium or Meteora launches. The Meteora-DBC-Bagsapp-Bundler (43 stars) provides bundling but not anti-sniper detection. The gap: protocol-agnostic anti-sniper protection for any Solana token launch venue.
timing_rationale: With 4,176 Metaplex tx/hr of token creation and dedicated sniping infrastructure being built (DeFi repo forks at 229), the arms race between launchers and snipers is intensifying. Building the defense side of this arms race captures value from every token launcher who wants fair distribution — and the 43-star Meteora bundler shows launchers are already seeking this type of tooling.

title: RWABridge — Real World Asset Discovery and Yield Comparison for Solana
description: A dashboard aggregating all 19 Solana RWA protocols into a single interface where users can discover, compare, and invest in real world asset products — treasuries, real estate, private credit, commodities — sorted by yield, risk rating, minimum investment, lock-up period, and underlying asset type. Pulls on-chain TVL data from each protocol and enriches with off-chain metadata (asset documentation, legal structure, audit status). The key insight: $6.9B in RWA TVL across 19 protocols but zero new repos means existing products are under-discovered, not over-built.
target_user: Crypto-native DeFi users holding stablecoins (USDC/USDT) earning 0% who want yield from real-world assets but don't know which of the 19 Solana RWA protocols to trust. Secondary: TradFi investors entering via ETF narrative who want on-chain RWA exposure. Pain point: RWA protocols are siloed — each has its own UI, documentation, and risk profile. No aggregator helps users compare. They'd use this because choosing between 19 RWA protocols manually is impractical.
mvp_scope: 1) RWA protocol registry: catalog all 19 Solana RWA protocols with program addresses, TVL (from on-chain), asset type (treasury, real estate, credit, commodity), minimum investment, lock-up period, and current yield. 2) Yield comparison dashboard: sort/filter by yield, asset type, minimum investment, and risk tier. Show yield curves over time for each protocol. 3) Risk scoring: rate each protocol on audit status, legal structure transparency, redemption history, and smart contract risk (proxy upgradability, admin key exposure). 4) One-click invest flow: for protocols that support it, provide direct deposit links with wallet connection. 5) Portfolio tracker: for users invested in multiple RWA protocols, show aggregate yield, maturity schedule, and rebalancing suggestions.
competitive_landscape: DefiLlama tracks RWA TVL but doesn't provide investment comparison or risk scoring. RWA.xyz covers Ethereum RWA but has limited Solana data. Individual protocols (Ondo, Maple, Credix) have their own UIs but no cross-protocol comparison. The gap: Solana has $6.9B in RWA TVL across 19 protocols and no aggregator — this is the 'Jupiter for RWA' opportunity.
timing_rationale: RWA at $6.9B TVL is the largest non-CEX, non-staking DeFi category on Solana, surpassing even lending ($5.5B). Zero new repos means no new entrants are building aggregation tools. The ETF narrative (16 filings) brings institutional attention that naturally flows toward RWA products. Building the aggregator now captures the intersection of institutional ETF interest and existing RWA TVL.

title: RWAYield — Stablecoin-to-RWA Yield Optimizer
description: An automated yield optimizer specifically for stablecoin holders that deploys USDC/USDT across Solana RWA protocols to maximize risk-adjusted yield. Unlike DeFi yield farming (which relies on token emissions), RWA yields are backed by real-world cash flows — treasuries, loans, real estate — making them more sustainable. The optimizer monitors yields across Ondo (tokenized treasuries), Maple/Credix (private credit), and other Solana RWA protocols, auto-rebalances based on yield differentials and user risk preferences.
target_user: Stablecoin whales ($100K+) who want sustainable yield without DeFi farming risk. Current pain: stablecoins on Solana earn minimal native yield — users must manually research and deploy across siloed RWA protocols. They'd switch from manual RWA allocation because auto-rebalancing captures higher blended yield without constant monitoring.
mvp_scope: 1) RWA yield monitor: poll on-chain yield data from top Solana RWA protocols every hour, track historical yield curves, and compute risk-adjusted returns (Sharpe ratio using yield volatility as risk proxy). 2) Risk preference profile: users select Conservative (treasuries only, max 5% yield), Balanced (treasuries + credit, 5-10%), or Aggressive (all asset types, 10%+). 3) Allocation engine: given risk profile and deposit amount, compute optimal allocation across RWA protocols to maximize yield within risk constraints. 4) Deposit/withdrawal interface: web UI with wallet connection for depositing USDC into the optimizer vault, which then deploys to selected RWA protocols. 5) Monthly yield report: show actual yield earned, allocation history, comparison against holding bare USDC, and next-month allocation plan.
competitive_landscape: Kamino vaults optimize DeFi yields but not RWA. Friktion (now defunct) had structured products but not RWA-specific. No existing Solana product aggregates RWA yields into a single optimized vault. On Ethereum, Superform aggregates yield vaults but doesn't focus on RWA. The gap: RWA yield optimization is an unoccupied niche on Solana despite $6.9B in TVL.
timing_rationale: $6.9B in RWA TVL with zero new repos means the capital is there but nobody is building aggregation tools. The lending TVL at $5.5B shows DeFi users are yield-hungry. The 19 RWA protocols create enough diversity that aggregation adds genuine value — with fewer protocols, a single UI would suffice. ETF institutional attention makes sustainable RWA yield products the obvious next narrative.

title: RWAGap — RWA Builder Opportunity Scanner
description: A research tool and weekly report identifying underserved niches in the Solana RWA ecosystem by analyzing the gap between TVL concentration and protocol coverage. Maps $6.9B across 19 protocols to identify: which asset classes are over/under-represented, which protocols are capturing disproportionate TVL, where new entrants could compete, and what infrastructure (oracles, custody, compliance) is missing. Think 'market research as a service' for RWA builders considering building on Solana.
target_user: RWA protocol builders and VCs evaluating the Solana RWA opportunity. Pain point: the zero-new-repos signal could mean either 'market is mature' or 'market has unseen gaps' — this tool disambiguates by mapping TVL to protocol coverage to find whitespace. They'd use this because empirical market mapping beats guesswork for build-or-invest decisions.
mvp_scope: 1) RWA protocol categorization: classify all 19 protocols by asset class (treasuries, real estate, private credit, commodities, equities, invoices) and map TVL per category. 2) Gap analysis: identify asset classes with high TradFi market size but low Solana RWA TVL (e.g., commodities tokenization, insurance-linked securities). 3) Infrastructure audit: check what RWA infrastructure exists on Solana (Pyth oracles for RWA pricing, compliance/KYC solutions, custodians) and where gaps block new protocol launches. 4) Competitive landscape per category: for each asset class, list existing protocols, their TVL, differentiation, and remaining whitespace. 5) Weekly newsletter: 'RWA Builder Brief' combining gap analysis with news (new filings, regulatory changes, protocol updates) to guide builders.
competitive_landscape: Messari and Delphi provide RWA research reports but not Solana-specific builder-oriented gap analysis. RWA.xyz tracks tokenized assets but doesn't map opportunities. No existing product combines on-chain TVL analysis with builder-oriented opportunity scoring for Solana RWA. The moat is the specificity: Solana + RWA + builder-oriented, not generic crypto research.
timing_rationale: Zero new RWA repos despite $6.9B TVL is the most actionable signal: capital without code means either moat or opportunity. The 19-protocol landscape is small enough to comprehensively map but large enough that gaps exist. ETF momentum (16 filings) will bring institutional capital that needs RWA products to park in. Builders who identify gaps now ship before the institutional wave arrives.
